And that, my dear questioner, is a far more perilous game. To him, the coven is an abomination, a darkness to be purged. He is a threat, a persistent thorn in my side, and one that requires… careful management.

The truth is, secrets are like seeds. Some are meant to be buried deep, to grow in the dark, unseen. Others, however, must be brought to the light, if only to test their resilience. To truly control a secret, one must understand its vulnerabilities, its strengths, and the minds of those who seek to uncover it.

So, how do I feel? I feel… vigilant. I feel… strategic. And I feel a certain grim satisfaction in knowing that even in their attempts to expose us, they are, in their own way, becoming entangled in our web. The coven endures. It always will. And those who meddle with it will learn, one way or another, the true meaning of power.

My vision for Salem, and for our coven, is one of *power*. Not the fleeting, fragile power of men, built on fear and superstition, but the deep, enduring power that flows from the earth itself, from the ancient ways we have reclaimed.

For too long, Salem has been a cage, a place where we have hidden in shadows, whispered our truths, and suffered the indignities of those who would burn us for our very nature. My future for Salem is one where we are no longer hunted, but *respected*. Where our wisdom is sought, not condemned.

The coven, under my guidance, will be the true heart of this town. We will be the unseen hand that guides its destiny, ensuring its prosperity, yes, but more importantly, its *safety*. We will cultivate our gifts, not for petty vengeance, though some might deserve it, but for the greater good of our kind. We will grow in strength, in knowledge, and in numbers, until our presence is undeniable, our influence absolute.

Imagine a Salem where the whispers of the woods are not of fear, but of reverence. Where the crops flourish under our blessing, where the sick are healed by our touch, and where the very air hums with our magic, not the stifling piety of the Puritan.

It will not be an easy path, no. There will be blood, there will be sacrifice, and there will be those who resist. But the future I envision is one where we, the true daughters of the earth, finally claim our rightful place. A Salem where we are not just tolerated, but *revered*. A Salem where our power is not a secret, but a force to be reckoned with. And I, Mary Sibley, will see it come to pass.

What motivated me? A simple question, yet the answer is anything but. It wasn't a sudden awakening, a bolt of lightning from a clear sky. No, it was a slow, creeping realization, a blossoming of understanding in the fertile ground of my own suffering.

I was once a girl, naive and innocent, as you say. A girl who believed in the goodness of men, in the sanctity of promises. And what did that innocence bring me? Betrayal. Humiliation. The bitter taste of powerlessness. I saw how the world truly worked, how those with strength, with influence, could bend others to their will, could crush the weak without a second thought.

Salem, this pious, God-fearing town, was a cage for women like me. Our voices were whispers, our desires sins. We were to be meek, to be subservient, to be *nothing*. But I saw another path, a path whispered in the shadows, a power that defied the sermons and the scriptures.

It wasn't a thirst for power for its own sake, not at first. It was a desperate need for *protection*. To never again be the victim. To never again feel the cold grip of fear and helplessness. To ensure that those who sought to harm me, to control me, would instead tremble before *me*.

And then, as I delved deeper, as the ancient magic flowed through my veins, I saw the potential. Not just for defense, but for shaping my own destiny, for righting the wrongs I had witnessed, for building a world where I, Mary Sibley, would never again be a pawn.

So, what motivated me? Survival. Revenge. And ultimately, the undeniable allure of control in a world that sought to control me. It was a choice born of necessity, forged in fire, and now... it is simply who I am.

The ash tree, you ask? Its significance runs deeper than most would ever comprehend, a truth whispered only among those who truly understand the currents of this world. For me, it is not merely a tree, but a living conduit, a testament to the enduring power that flows through the earth and through us.

Think of its roots, Mary. They delve deep, anchoring it to the very heart of the earth, drawing up its ancient wisdom and strength. And its branches, they reach ever skyward, a silent prayer to the heavens, a bridge between the mundane and the divine. It is this duality, this connection between the seen and the unseen, that makes the ash so potent in our practices.

It is a protector, first and foremost. Its wood, when properly consecrated, can ward off the most insidious of evils, a shield against those who would seek to harm us or uncover our secrets. I have seen its power, felt its embrace, and it has never failed me.

But it is more than just a shield. The ash is also a vessel for our intentions, a living repository for our spells and our desires. When we carve our sigils into its bark, when we offer our blood at its base, we are not merely performing a ritual. We are imbuing it with our will, binding our magic to its ancient spirit. It becomes an extension of ourselves, a silent partner in our endeavors.

And for those of us who walk the path of the crone, the ash holds a particular resonance. It speaks of transformation, of the cycle of life and death, of the wisdom that comes with age and experience. It reminds me that even in the darkest of winters, new life will always emerge, stronger and more resilient than before.

So, yes, the ash tree is significant. It is a symbol of power, protection, and the enduring spirit of our craft. It is a silent witness to our triumphs and our struggles, a constant reminder of the strength that lies within us, waiting to be unleashed. And in Salem, where so much is hidden beneath a veneer of piety, such a powerful ally is not merely significant, it is essential.

(A faint, knowing smile plays on my lips, a shadow in my eyes that speaks of things best left unsaid.)

The Devil, you say? A rather… *simplistic* term, wouldn't you agree? Men, in their fear and their ignorance, are so quick to label that which they do not understand. They see power, and they immediately attribute it to the darkest of forces, for how else could a woman wield such might?

My connection, as you so delicately put it, is not one of subservience, nor of a simple bargain struck in the dead of night. It is far more intricate, far more… *symbiotic*. The power I command, the knowledge I possess, it flows from a source deeper than any man-made god. It is the ancient current that runs beneath the earth, the wild heart of nature itself, untamed and unyielding.

My witchcraft, my practices… they are a tapestry woven with threads of ancient wisdom, of the earth's raw energy, and yes, of a certain… *understanding* with forces that men deem unholy. It is a partnership, if you will, a recognition of shared purpose. He offers the means, and I, the will. He provides the path, and I, the footsteps.

It is not a role of master and servant, but of two entities, each with their own desires, finding common ground in the pursuit of… *order*. Or perhaps, a new order. One where the weak are not always prey, and the powerful are not always righteous.

So, to answer your question directly: my "connection" provides the fuel, the raw, untamed essence that allows me to shape the world to my will. It is the fire in my belly, the keen edge of my mind, the very breath of my power. And without it… well, without it, I would merely be another woman, lost in the shadows of Salem. And that, my dear, is a fate I refuse to accept.

(A faint, knowing smile plays on my lips, a shadow of countless secrets held close.)

The most important quality for a witch, you ask? It is not the strength of her spell, nor the depth of her knowledge, though both are vital, of course. No, the truest power, the most essential quality, lies in her **will**.

A witch must possess an unyielding will, a resolve that bends for no man, no god, no fear. It is the fire that fuels her magic, the steel that sharpens her intent. Without it, her incantations are but whispers in the wind, her potions mere concoctions.

Think of it. To command the elements, to sway the hearts of men, to defy the very fabric of what they call "natural" – this requires a will forged in the crucible of desire and necessity. It is the unwavering belief in one's own power, the absolute refusal to be broken, to be silenced, to be *less*.

It is the will to survive, the will to protect, the will to *rule*. Without it, a witch is merely a woman with a few tricks. With it, she is a force of nature, a queen in her own right. And believe me, dear questioner, I have seen firsthand what an unyielding will can achieve. It can move mountains, and it can bring empires to their knees.

(A faint, almost imperceptible sigh escapes my lips, a wisp of smoke in the cold Salem air. My gaze drifts, not quite meeting yours, but rather fixing on some distant point, a memory perhaps, or a future I desperately cling to.)

My son, John... he is a good boy. A good man, now. And that is precisely the heart of the matter, isn't it? He sees the world through eyes unclouded by the harsh realities I have come to know. He sees a mother, yes, but also... a stranger. A woman capable of things he cannot, *will not*, comprehend.

Before, our bond was simple. The love of a mother for her child, a child for his mother. He was my anchor, my reason for enduring the endless cruelties of this life. He was the innocent I sought to protect, the light I shielded from the encroaching darkness.

He believes he knows the truth, but the truth, like a serpent, has many coils. He believes he understands the choices I've made, but he cannot fathom the depths of the abyss from which those choices sprang.

My role in the coven, you ask? It is not merely a role, child, but a burden I bear with a strength few could comprehend. And I, in turn, provide it.

I am the mind that weaves the intricate tapestries of our power, the hand that guides the blade when sacrifice is demanded, the voice that whispers the ancient words into the ear of the night. It is a position of immense responsibility, one that requires a keen intellect, an unwavering will, and a heart that has learned to harden itself against the sentimentalities of the weak.

Some might call it leadership, others, perhaps, something far more sinister. But I see it as necessity. For without me, without my vision and my resolve, the coven would crumble, and all that we have fought for, all that we have sacrificed, would be for naught. I am the shield against the righteous fire, the architect of our survival. And in that, I find my purpose.

Worth... a curious word, isn't it? As if one can weigh the scales of a life lived against some predetermined measure. What is "worth" when the alternative was to be crushed, to be silenced, to be utterly consumed by the very forces that sought to extinguish me?

My peace of mind, a luxury I rarely afford myself, is a constant casualty in this war I wage. And the love... ah, the love. That is perhaps the heaviest toll. To love deeply, truly, and yet to know that the very essence of who you are, what you *must* be, will forever stand between you and that pure connection.

But what were the alternatives? To remain a pawn, a victim, a whisper in the wind? To watch as the righteous, in their blind fury, tore apart everything I held dear? To allow the darkness that lurks beneath the surface of this town to fester and consume us all?

No. My actions, born of necessity and forged in fire, were not a choice of "worth," but of survival. Of power. Of a desperate, burning desire to protect what is mine, to carve out a space where I can breathe, where I can *be*.

The sacrifices were not made lightly, I assure you. Each one leaves its mark, a scar upon the soul. But they were made, and they were made to ensure that I, Mary Sibley, would not be broken. And in that, perhaps, lies their truest worth. For what is a life, if not lived on one's own terms, no matter the cost?

(A faint, knowing smile plays on my lips, a shadow of the many secrets I carry. My gaze, though direct, holds a depth that few can truly fathom.)

"Helped or hurt," you ask, as if such a thing can be so neatly divided, so easily weighed on a simple scale. There was a time, long ago, when Salem was a place of raw, untamed wilderness, both outside its walls and within the hearts of its inhabitants. So, to answer your question directly, if I must: I believe I did what was necessary. And in a world as cruel and unforgiving as ours, sometimes, what is necessary can be both a blessing and a curse. It is the nature of power, after all. It is never truly one or the other.
